news four-ways-make-your-christmas-"Coronavirus in numbers: UK records , new casesAdvertorialByNatasha YoungCommercial Audience Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Jan Those long-awaited Christmas get-togethers with family and friends are just around the corner, but with the highly transmissible Omicron iant spreading fast it’s important to take some extra steps to make your celebrations Covid-safe. Close contact with others – especially in unventilated spaces – increases your chances of spreading Covid-. If you’re spending the festive season with loved ones there are lots of ways you can reduce the risk, including taking regular rapid lateral flow tests, letting fresh air in and getting your booster. GP Dr Claire Ashley provides some simple tips for staying safe so you and those close to you can gather round the table and enjoy your Christmas fun. Take those tests  Meeting up with loved ones  You should all do a rapid lateral flow test before you mingle.They’re free, easy to do at home and the results show in half an hour – to order a pack, go to nhs.uk get-tested.“If you haven’t got any symptoms, rapid lateral flow tests are very good at picking up Covid-,” says Dr Ashley, based in the South West. “On Christmas morning, before granny comes over for lunch, taking a test is the best way to check you’re not infectious. “My family will all have a rapid lateral flow test the morning we travel down to see my parents, andanything comes back positive, or any of us has symptoms, we won’t go. “I’m aware our plans might be disrupted. It’s not perfect, especially after last year, but I’d rather everyone stays safe.”  As Dr Ashley points out, rapid lateral flow tests are designed to pick up Covid- cases with no symptoms, soyou do have symptoms such as a fever, cough or loss of sense of taste or smell, you need to isolate immediately and take a PCR test. Andyour rapid lateral flow test does show a positive result, you’ll need to isolate and only leave the house to take a PCR test to confirm it.If you have been in contact with someone with Covid- and are double vaccinated, you should take a daily rapid lateral flow test for seven daysyou have no symptoms. If you test positive or develop symptoms in those seven days, you must self-isolate, take a PCR test and follow the guidance on gov.uk.If you are unvaccinated, you must self-isolate for  daysyou are in contact with someone who has Covid-.Don’t forget the NHS COVID- app is still the fastest way to knowyou’ve been exposed to someone who’s tested positive, so keep it on.Open the window sLetting fresh air into your home is one way to help reduce the spread of Covid-. Opening windows and doors for just  minutes will help. “Covid- is an airborne virus and the research suggests that when you’re in a well-ventilated space the risk of contracting it is reduced,” says Dr Ashley. “That’s why being outdoors is much more safe, but that’s tricky when it’s very cold. Soyou want to reduce the chances of Covid- being passed on, have the windows open so you get as much airflow as possible.” Wear a face covering You must wear a face covering in public areas such as shops, places of worship, entertainment venues, and on public transport. It’s wise to wear a mask in crowded or enclosed spaces, eventhey’re not legally required. “Face coverings are really effective at reducing how much you’re spreading Covid-,” explains Dr Ashley. Get your booster Every adult in the country now needs to get a Covid- booster vaccine, because two doses does not give you enough protection against catching Omicron. Book yours now at nhs.uk covidvaccination.Get Boosted Now is the national mission to build a wall of defence against the Omicron iant. This mission is more urgent than ever before with Covid- because Omicron is spreading fast. Vaccines are the best way we can protect ourselves. You can get a Covid- booster  weeks after your second dose. Boosters give you the best possible protection against the virus and should signicantly reduce your risk of serious illness and hospitalisation.If you haven’t had your first or second vaccine, go to nhs.uk covidvaccination or call  to book it, or find your nearest walk-in centre.“It’s also very important for pregnant women to get vaccinated,” adds Dr Ashley. “The benefits of being vaccinated and boosted really outweigh the risks.”People with lower immune systems might need to be more careful about socialising this Christmas, as they could have less protection against getting severely ill with Covid-. This includes people who are taking medication that suppresses the immune system – eg, for rheumatoid arthritis – and those having chemotherapy. For more advice on celebrating the festive season safely, visit: gov.uk coronavirus Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CoronavirusMost ReadRecommended

title: broken levelling up promises laid
story: Exclusive: Crumbling school with leaky roof exposes sick truth of Tories failure to level up UKThe Mirror visits a school in desperate need of investment as we launch Levelling Up Watch, holding the Government to account for its plans to improve education, communities and transportSchool headteacher Giuseppe DiLasio says the school is in desperate need of investment Image: SWNSByLucy ThorntonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsWe today reveal the truth behind Tory levelling up claims as one head teacher tells of a crumbling school building with no funding for repairs. Pepe Di’Iasio’s school in Yorkshire has more than  leaks in the roof, leaving his pupils “cold and wet”. As we launch Levelling up Watch, Mr Di’Iasio said: “Words are cheap, actions speak louder than words.”Mr Di’Iasio dreads the rain. Dreads it because the school roof leaks and staff will be running around classrooms to place buckets to catch the water. It’s just one more problem in a Covid-hit educational world that has caused such anxiety for his pupils that some have turned up drunk for lessons, while others have been traumatised by domestic violence. The school has used all its cash reserves putting support in place. Di’Iasio says: “We’ve done our best to try to prioritise people, not spend money on bricks and mortar.” But the -year-old building is in desperate need of investment.  The clapped-out drains are collapsing, there are cracks in windows caused by subsidence, water comes through the flat roof in at least  places, and the technology building has been closed because it is in such a state. Site manager Martin Smith gives us a tour of Wales High School near Sheffield, South Yorks, and says: “It’s just a nightmare, we’re forever mopping up.” We stop to chat to two caretakers, one has  keys hanging on a chain around his neck as the locks have not been upgraded since the school opened in . The caretakers are fixing a huge fan heater and, with a sigh, one explains: “It’s broken again. Everything is just tired out.”  There are , pupils, aged  to , at the school, where carpets are stained from the leaks and ceiling tiles are missing where caretakers burst them to release the build-up of water. Science teachers were furious last term when water came through and destroyed crucial coursework. But despite the struggles, Mr Di’Iasio and the caretakers could not be more proud of their secondary school and their “amazing” pupils. The devotion of the staff is clear – during lockdown, the kitchen staff and cleaners repainted the whole school. It may not be pretty, but Wales High School, rated “Good” by Ofsted, is so popular parents fight to get their kids places, with at least  appeals every year when admission is refused.  The school tries to keep up with this demand, even converting staff toilets to classrooms. Head of School, Lisa McCall lost half her office to accommodate students. She says: “I can hear the lesson next door and I have to whisperdiscussing anything confidential because of the thin partition.” Mr Di’Iasio invited the Mirror into the school to show how desperately funding is needed. He has seen no sign of the promised levelling up or extra money for schools. He says: “It’s hard to believe we are in the world’s sixth-largest economy. Levelling up is supposed to be the big idea of Boris Johnson’s government.When he was elected in  he pledged to spread opportunity to every corner of the UK. But two years later we are still waiting for the Prime Minister to deliver on his promises. A White Paper setting out the Government’s plan was supposed to have been published this month but has now been shelved until the new year.Many are starting to question whether Mr Johnson is genuinely committed to spreading wealth and opportunity orlevelling up is just an empty slogan. That is why the Mirror is today launching Levelling Up Watch. We intend to hold the Government to account over its plans to improve schools, communities, education and transport. We also want to see any additional money distributed fairly and not just to seats the Tories need to retain to stay in power. What is clear is tinkering with the structure of local government and sprinkling money on piecemeal transport schemes will not be enough. The regional inequality in Britain is not only deep and engrained, it has become starker since the Conservatives came to power in . During that period more than , Sure Start Centres have closed, local councils have seen their funding cut by more than % and the budgets for public health and education have been badly squeezed. The National Audit Office found that since , funding in the most deprived fth of schools fell in real terms by .%, while funding in the fth least deprived schools rose by .%. The additional money announced by Chancellor Rishi Sunak in his Budget will onlyper pupil funding to  levels. People in poorer areas are likely to have worse health and shorter le expectancy but the budget for Public Health England in - is % – £billion – lower in real terms than in -. Nor can it be right that - transport spending was £ per capita in London, compared to £ in the North East and £ in Yorkshire and Humber. We have heard plenty of words from Mr Johnson about his ambitions to level up but the time for rhetoric is over. We need to see some action.  “We are in a s building and as we speak the rain is pouring down. “I have no doubt that we will have more than five or six dferent leaks, with buckets in classrooms, by the end of the day. We are in a school where children will be cold and wet. “This at a time when we are keeping windows open to allow airflow to prevent the spread of Covid, and the heating is working overtime to keep the temperature at a level you can work and learn in. “Our site staff are brilliant at trying to make do and mend, but the building is creaking and when it rains the flat roof leaks. It has been patched up as much as it possibly can be. “The building is not really fit for purpose and the environment can have a massive impact on learning.”  Mr Di‘Iasio is also dealing with the impact of Covid on his pupils’ mental health. He says: “We are dealing with the fallout from that from a large number of students on a daily basis. “Initially when the students came back they were just so happy to be back, but then things changed and they started exhibiting more extremes of behaviour than we had before. “We had students turning up with alcohol, being under the influence. “We had students who had the police in the house overnight dealing with incidents of domestic violence and we’ve had incidents where students have been suffering from the pressure of the exam process.  “We have spent our money making sure we keep our staff and have enough people to support the students. “There is more money now invested in mental health support and wellbeing.” The school stayed open the first week of the Christmas holidays so pupils could get hot meals. All of the school’s reserves, £,, have now gone. Mr Di‘Iasio says: “The students make the job worthwhile, they make every day a happy day. But it’s when you are looking at the budget and having to make really tough decisions about whether to keep that counsellor or that classroom assistant. They are the darkest days. “But we love our school.” About levelling up, Mr Di‘Iasio says: “I am massively in favour of the concept, but words are cheap and actions speak louder than words. A Department for Education spokesperson said: “We have invested £. billion since  to enable schools to refurbish their buildings, including £. billion in - alone.On top of this, our new ten-year School Rebuilding Programme to transform  schools is underway and will improve the education of tens of thousands of children as we level up across the UK.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchoolsMental healthSecondary schoolLevelling Up Watch" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics major-covid-rule-change-coming-"Dr Hilary discusses easing of PCR test rulesByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A new rule change is set to come into effect tomorrow, as the government works on keeping on top of coronavirus case numbers. There have been dficulties keeping track of case numbers in recent weeks due to shortages of lateral flow testsand polymerase chain reactiontests. Despite this, case numbers have remained high and have reached record levels since the Omicron iant took a hold on the country. The UKaposs official Covid death toll passed , on Saturday January . Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs government is currently drawing up plan for a living with Covid strategy, which aims to avoid any long-term restrictions in England from March this year.The proposed rule changes may seem like a contradiction to some, so what are they and who do they affect  What is the PCR test rule change   Currently, people who test positive for Covid with no symptoms on a lateral flow test are required to take a PCR to confirm their status. This will change from January .They will still have to isolate for at least seven days, but only from the date of their positive lateral flow test.Head of Imperial College Londonaposs Department of Primary Care  Public Health, Professor Azeem Majeed told the i that the move is a positive step. He said: If you’re positive on lateral flow teststhat’s almost certainly diagnostic of a Covid- infection in the current situation we’re in, as infection rates are so high.By not then having to take a PCR test, it takes pressure off the PCR testing system. What should I doI have a positive LFT   Anyone who tests positive for the virus through an LFT should report their status immediately. The UK Health Security Agencyhas given guidance of how to do this and what will occur afterwards.They said: Under this new approach, anyone who receives a positive LFD test result should report their result on Gov.UK and must self-isolate immediately but will not need to take a follow-up PCR test. At the moment, isolation rules mean that a fully vaccinated person can stop isolating after seven days, proving they take a lateral flow test every day and are negative on days six and seven and have no symptoms. A move to a five-day isolation period is now under consideration. The PM told reporters today: Yes of course, we are looking at that and we will act accordingly to the science as we always have. Is the change to testing permanent   The change brought in has been described as a temporary measure while cases remain high. The UKHSA said: This is a temporary measure while Covid- rates remain high across the UK. Whilst levels of Covid- are high, the vast majority of people with positive [LFT] results can be confident that they have Covid-. The idea is that while cases are in such high numbers, symptoms and a positive test are more likely than normal to indicate the virus. Meanwhile, while case numbers are infrequent and low, a PCR test might be needed to show a positive infection.  The new approach reflects similar changes made this time last year in January , when there was also a high prevalence of infection meaning it was highly likely that a positive [LFT] Covid- result was a true positive. This meant confirmatory PCRs were temporarily paused and reintroduced in March  following a reduction in prevalence. news politics moment-tories-ordered-brits-not-"Oliver Dowden advises people to stay at home in May ByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Jan | commentsThis is the astonishing moment a Cabinet minister ordered the nation not to gather outdoors -  minutes before  No staff had a garden party. Oliver Dowden issued the warning moments before the “bring your own booze” bash - which multiple sources claim Boris Johnson attended with his we Carrie. And just five days later, the Prime Minister himself said police should intervene to stop people having outdoor parties. Mr Johnson has been plunged into a fresh scandal over the bash on May , .A bombshell e-mail obtained by ITV News showed more than  No staff were invited by the PM’s top civil servant and told to ‘bring your own booze’.Outdoor gatherings were banned in England at the time under Covid rules. Now footage has emerged of then-Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden speaking at a No press conference, just  minutes before the pm bash out the back door.  He urged hard-pressed citizens to “limit contact with other people”, and said: “You can meet one person outside of your household in an outdoor, public place - provided that you stay two metres apart. The Cabinet minister warned “staying alert for the vast majority of people still means staying at home as much as possible.”Mr Dowden added: “If everyone stays alert and follows the rules, we can control coronavirus.“This is how we can continue to save lives and livelihoods as we begin as a nation to recover from coronavirus.”  Just five days after the outdoor gathering, Boris Johnson said police should intervene to stop outdoor gatherings. He was asked by a member of the public: “There are large groups gathering in local parks, ignoring social distancing rules. When many of us are being so vigilant and staying alert, what can be done to discourage this disregard for the rules ” The PM replied: “Feel free to speak to people yourselfyou feel that they are not obeying the rules. “But the police will step innecessary and encourage people to obey the law. Boris Johnson ’s Principal Private Secretary Martin Reynolds faces a fight for his job after the May  e-mail was revealed by ITV News. And sources now expect Whitehallaposs parties investigator Sue Gray will have to interview the Prime Minister himself - as he was said to have been present at four of the events she is looking into.In a screenshot of the email obtained by ITV News, Mr Reynolds wrote: Hi all, after what has been an incredibly busy period it would be nice to make the most of the lovely weather and have some socially distanced drinks in the No garden this evening.Please join us from pm and bring your own booze!According to the BBC, staff raised questions privately at the time with one saying: “Um. Why is Martin encouraging a mass gathering in the garden ”.Another wrote: “Is this for real ” The May  gathering was revealed last week by ex-Downing Street aideDominic Cummings , who has gone to war with his former boss since leaving Government in November .Hannah Brady, spokesperson for Covid  Bereaved Families for Justice, said: My Dad died just four days before this email was sent out, he was only  and was a fit and healthy key worker.” She added: “How can those running the country have thought it was OK  Could there be a more disgraceful example of aposone rule for them, and another rule for the rest of usapos  “To make matters worse, in September last year I sat in that same Garden, looked the Prime Minister in the eyes and told him how my dad had died. “He told me he had ‘done everything he could’ to protect my Dad, knowing that he had partied in that same spot the very day that Dad’s death certicate was signed. “It makes me feel sick to think about it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonCabinetCivil servantsPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mp says no longer silenced
story: MP says she is no longer silenced after court found she was raped by MP ex-husbandKate Grfiths said her ex-husband and former minister Andrew Grfiths was a charmer when they first met, but by the end I had just become a shadow of my former selfTory MP Kate Grfiths outside the Royal Courts of Justice Image: PAByBrian Farmer:,  Jan A Tory MP found to have been raped by her politician ex-husband has spoken of her “feeling of freedom” after the court finding was made public. Kate Grfiths said I am no longer silenced by the family courts” and I can speak out” after a y saga involving her ex Andrew Grfiths. Mr Grfiths used to be the MP for Burton and the minister for small business, and once worked as former prime minister Theresa Mayaposs chief of staff.He resigned in  after the Sunday Mirror revealed he sent depraved messages to two constituents. The Grfiths, both , became embroiled in private family court proceedings, centred on a child, after separating.During those proceedings, a family court judge concluded that, on the balance of probability, Mr Grfiths had raped and physically abused Ms Grfiths.  Ms Grfiths was speaking on a Tortoise Media podcast after Court of Appeal judges ruled the rape finding could be made public. Ms Grfiths said the pair met in  before Mr Grfiths became an MP, and began a relationship  months later. He was great, he was funny, he was a charmer, said Ms Grfiths. I thought he was an all-round good guy. He was very attentive. Ms Grfiths said people would say they were an ideal couple. But she added: By the end of the relationship, I had just become a shadow of my former self. Three appeal judges last month ruled the family court judgeaposs findings could be made public after a -month legal fight by two media organisations - Tortoise and PA Media. Ms Grfiths had waived her right to anonymity and supported the fight by journalists. She said publication would allow her to help constituents. Itaposs like a feeling of freedom, she said. Mr Grfiths had strongly denied allegations made against him, and argued that the family court judgeaposs findings should not be made public. He said the judgeaposs findings should stay private in order to protect the child at the centre of the case. Judges ruled that neither the gender nor the name of the child at the centre of proceedings could be revealed in media reports. title: omicron cases peaked what latest
story: Have Omicron cases peaked  What the latest Covid data tells us about infectionsAny impact on the spread of Covid from children going back to school after the Christmas break or from people ing to work after New Years have yet to become clearThe number of cases being reported each day has been disrupted by the Christmas and new year holidays Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByIan Jones:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments While the number of new daily Covid cases in the UK has now fallen for five days in a row, experts say it’s too soon to know for surethis means the Omicron surge has peaked.Any impact on the spread of the virus from children going back to school after the Christmas break, or from people ing to work after the new year, has yet to become clear.The figures for new cases are likely to be influenced by how many people are actually taking lateral flow tests and reporting the results, while the time taken for specimens to be processed and reported by laboratories has been affected by the huge volume of tests being handled.But the number of cases being reported each day has been disrupted by the Christmas and new year holidays, which in turn has added to the backlog of cases being announced. The day-on-day change in the total UK reported cases also masks changes in the separate nations and regions, with some areas of the country now behaving dferently from others.  Cases Looking at the number of new cases by specimen date - when a person actually tested positive, rather than when it was reported - the rate has continued to increase in England and Northern Ireland but may have levelled off in Wales and Scotland. Northern Ireland has the highest rate of the four nations, with ,. cases per , people in the seven days to January , according to Government data. This is the highest rate for Northern Ireland since mass testing began in the UK in summer . England is also at a record high, with ,. cases per , people. But the latest figures for Wales and Scotlandare lower than in recent days. Data for cases by specimen date after January  are incomplete, which is why the numbers for January  onwards are not included. Further dferences are evident when looking at case rates for inidual regions in England, with the North West, North East and Yorkshire all now seeing higher rates than London. In north-east England, ,. cases per , people were recorded in the seven days to January , while north-west England recorded . and Yorkshire Humber ... By contrast, London is currently recording ,. cases per ,, below its recent peak of ,. on December . Of the top  highest local authority case rates in England, seven are in north-west Englandwhile the other three are in north-east England .  Hospitals There is a similar north-south ide emerging in hospital numbers.A total of , Covid- patients were in hospital in north-west England as of am on January , the equivalent of  per cent of the regionaposs second-wave peak of , nearly one year earlier.In north-east England and Yorkshire, , patients were recorded on January , or  per cent of its second-wave peak of ,. The percentages are much lower in other regions, however. In London and the Midlands, hospital numbers are currently just under a half what they were at the peak of the second wave , while south-west England and eastern England are about a thirdand south-east England just  per cent, according to analysis by the PA news agency. London, south-east England and south-west England have all seen a drop in Covid- hospital patients in the last few days, while numbers have continued to rise in other regions. Asked on Monday whether the current wave of cases is over in London but not where in the country, Graham Medley, professor of infectious disease modelling at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: I think that at the moment the testing capacity issues, and the Christmas and the new year, mean that we canapost really rely on cases to tell us whataposs going to happen exactly.At the moment we are seeing a relatively high number of admissions how long that continues, whether that goes up or goes down, I think is unknown at the moment. Most regions have seen a week-on-week fall in hospital admissions, though the numbers have dropped only slightly and the long-term trend is not clear. What is clear is that the number of Covid- hospital patients in England in mechanical ventilator beds remains low, with  recorded on January , down from  a week earlier and below the number on December  . This reflects a major dference between the current wave and the wave that hit the UK one year ago.Chris Hopson, chief executive of NHS Providers, described the peak in January  as one that saw hospitals focused on expanding critical care for large numbers of very ill, often older people, needing serious y treatment.The current peak is about expanding general and acute beds for large numbers of people with much milder disease symptoms, he tweeted on Saturday.  Infections The most comprehensive snapshot of how many people in the UK are likely to have Covid- can be found in the weekly infection survey from the Office for National Statistics- and this too suggests there are now dferent trends in the nations and regions. While all parts of the country likely had a record level of infections in the week to December  - the latest available estimate - in London there were early signs in the last few days of  that infections may no longer be increasing, but it is currently too early to suggestthis is a continuing change in trend, the ONS said. London also saw the smallest week-on-week growth in infection rates, up slightly from . per cent to . per cent. But the rate almost doubled in north-east England, from . per cent to . per cent, and more than doubled in north-west England, from . per cent to . per cent Northern Ireland had the lowest percentage of people who were estimated to have Covid- in the week to December while England had the highest , a reverse of the picture suggested by the data for case rates, with Wales on . per cent and Scotland . per cent. The infection survey is based on a sample of swab tests collected from households across the UK and estimates the prevalence of Covid- within the entire community population, regardless of when people caught the virus, how long they have had it, and whether they have symptoms.By contrast, the number of cases of Covid- reported each day by the Government includes only those people who have newly tested positive for the virus, and is therefore affected by how many people are coming forward for tests, or who are taking a test because they know they have coronavirus symptoms.Results from the next infection survey are due to be published on Wednesday and this will give the most reliable guide to- and where - the current surge in coronavirus has peaked. title: over promising under delivering hallmark
story: Over-promising and under-delivering is a hallmark of Prime Minister Boris JohnsonToday the Daily Mirror takes a detailed look at le in areas the Conservatives claim they now care about with the launch of our Levelling up Watch - and the picture is bleakWales Highschool is in desperate need of investment Image: SWNSopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsAs empty political slogans go, “Levelling Up” must be among the emptiest ever created by masters of the art the Tories. Today the Daily Mirror takes a detailed look at le in areas the Conservatives claim they now care about. The picture is bleak, with little or no progress since Boris Johnson won an -seat majority at the  General Election. Over-promising and under-delivering is a hallmark of this Prime Minister. The rundown school we highlight today, where heroic teachers and other staff struggle to keep going in crumbling buildings, is unfortunately not an exception. Working people deserve better and the pupils deserve an education in fit-for-purpose facilities. But in this country Government policies are levelling us down instead of up. Staff our NHS  With an understaffed NHS on its knees, axing key staff because they are unvaccinated would be self-destructive. The boss of one of London’s busiest hospitals warning as many as % of his workforce could need moving shows what happens when the tricky real world collides with Whitehall diktat. Of course, those in the health service should be jabbed, to protect patients, colleagues and the public as well as themselves. Yet the no jab, no job order could prove ruinous to the provision of healthcare. Daily pre-work tests are expensive and burdensome but it would surely be better to use them than to lose the skills and expertise of people who, for whatever reason, have failed to get inoculated, or chosen not to. Pitch in, Andy The Duke of York’s ongoing legal troubles in the US civil courts cast a dark shadow over the Queen’s planned Platinum Jubilee celebrations in early June. If Prince Andrew wants to make a positive contribution to the national occasion, he should bake his mum a cake to mark it. It’d be no sweat. news politics uproar-colston-statue-verdict-another-"Edward Colston statue: Protesters cleared of criminal damageopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsDonapost worry about declining living standards because Boris Johnson is going to save statues of slave traders. Forget record high NHS waiting lists and crumbling schools when Tory Cabinet Ministers lie in front of giant Union Jacks to illustrate their intense patriotism. And ignore sleaze, corruption, back-handers, unfairness, inequality and fatal mistakes for, with the blessing of Culture Wars Secretary Nadine Dorries, Tory no-mark Andrew Rosindell wants the BBC to play God Save the Queen every day. Statues, flags and anthems are battlegrounds the PM’s smokescreen to ert public attention away from his tax hikes, soaring fuel bills, cost of living rises, stagnant wages and declining public services.  It is a classic, cynical Right-wing strategy to ide and rule. It played well in the past and it might work again. Magicians use misdirection as a form of deception to draw the audience’s attention from the real action. Johnson would rather voters were angry about a jury clearing four protesters over the toppling of slaver Edward Colston’s statue in Bristol than holding the PM to account for increased National Insurance or discussing Labour’s proposed windfall tax on North Sea oil and gas producers to compensate households who are facing huge increases in energy bills.  Suella Braverman is an Attorney-General whose ideological conviction results in much of the legal profession judging her guilty of stupidity. Even considering an appeal against the jury verdict in the Colston case is a sign the governing party will roll in the gutter. Labour leader Keir Starmer is wise to take no lectures on patriotism from a Conservative regime which inflicted the terrible national self-harm that is Brexit. But in a fight, the Labour leader is similarly wise to combat smears which saw predecessor Jeremy Corbyn unfairly tainted as hating his country. Labour wins by keeping the national conversation on big issues that really count, the Tories by changing it to emblems and frippery. Living standards or statues  The election’s choice and verdict will decide whether Britain is a progressive country moving brightly forward or stuck in the past. title: 5 things happen you stop
story: things that happen when you stop drinking alcohol - from better skin to weight lossThe benefits of cutting back on booze can be seen both in the long and short term, ranging from staving off hangovers and bad skin all the way to decreasing the risks of cancerCutting back on booze can have a iety of long and short term benefits for your health Image: Getty ImagesByHarry Thompson:,  Oct Updated:,  Jan | comments Living a booze free le isnapost for everyone, but it is a simple fact that those that do are more likely to reap a host of dferent health-related rewards for their commitment to sobriety. A iety of things happen to your body over time when you give up drinking, with organised events like Dry January and Sober October having a positive effects on your body. Charity Drinkaware has have compiled information on a iety dferent changes you can expect to see in your body across both the long and short term, from superficial changes to appearance to staving off le threatening issues.What are the short term changes you can expect to see when you stop drinking   Youaposll stop getting hangoversThis might sound obvious. No drink, no hangover. But think about what a stinking hangover really feels like: relentless nausea, anxiety, fatigue, headaches, shakes and perhaps even vomiting. Now imagine not feeling any of these things. This is about as shirt term as it comes but its also a way to get a sense of near-instant gratication.Your mental health will improve Drinking heavily and regularly can have impacts on how your brain s. The chemicals in your brain that are vital for good mental health are interfered with when you drink heavily. That first drink may feel like a moment of respite and relief, but in the long run it is more likely to contribute to feelings of anxiety and depression: By cutting it out, yourapose also more likely to lower your stress levels too. Better sleep, more energy Cutting booze out completely is a surefire way to help regulate your sleeping pattern and bump up your energy levels. Drinking disrupts your sleep cycle: while a drink before bed can help you fall into a deep slumber, itaposs likely to lead you into increased rates of Rapid Eye Movement or aposREMapos sleep. This kind of tossing and turning less restful and can leave you feeling tired the next day. If you cut down the booze youaposre also likely to cut down the REM, meaning more good hours in the bank, an easier wake up in the morning and a better feeling throughout the day. Your skin will look better Booze dehydrates your body every time you drink. It can give a aposdullapos impression to your skin and eyes, likely making you look more tired than you already are. If you cut it down both your skin and eyes should brighten back up after nought time.  You could loose weight Drinkaware says: A pint of lager can contain the same amount of calories as a slice of pizza, or a large glass of wine the same an ice cream sundae. Booze is full of aposempty caloriesapos that cause wight gain without providing any nutritional benefits to your body in other ways. If yo cut down on the drinks youaposll also be cutting down on the calories, improvising your overall ratios between calories burned and calories ingested. Drinking alcohol can also reduce your bodyaposs fat burning process when itaposs looking for an energy supply, meaning that when you stop this process will become more effective and you will begin to burn fat in a more normal way. If you loose weight after cutting back on the beverages thereaposs a good chance you can also keep the weight offyou donapost start drinking too much afterwards. What are the long term benefits of giving up alcohol   Seven dferent kinds of cancer are linked to alcohol consumption, including breast and mouth, so by cutting back you decrease the risk of developing them. title: bomb squad called after over
story: Bomb squad called after over , explosives found underwater by magnetic fishermenThe group of magnetic fishermen, who use strong magnets on a rope to hunt for metal objects underwater, found a haul of around , explosive devicesMagnetic fishing fan Sophie Doyle says police were shocked by their find Image: MENByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsAround , explosives have been found underwater by a group of keen magnetic fishermen. Emergency services, including the bomb squad, were called by the hobbyists who found the stash during an event on Sunday . It is believed the devices were long-forgotten railway explosives.Sophie Doyle who runs the Magnetic Pull Facebook group for the fishermen - who use a strong magnet attached to a rope to discover metal objects underwater - told the Manchester Evening News : “The police and the bomb squad were really shocked when they saw the big pile of explosives that we had piled on the floor for them.We werenapost able to identy what model they were, there were so many dferent models of them.  “They had been there for a very long time.” The haul, found in Daisy Nook Country Park near Oldham, was the second found by the group in a week as they also found more than  explosives the weekend before.A spokesperson for Greater Manchester Police said: Officers were called to a report of possible unexploded devices found in a canal in Daisy Nook Country Park in Stannybrook Road, Failsworth, just after .pm on Sunday . Officers and the Explosive Ordnance Disposal Unitwere in attendance alongside Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service.A -metre cordon was in place as a precaution. All devices were removed and the area open again at pm.  Devices were taken away by the EOD for testing. Last year a group of magnet fishermen found a body in Rochdale Canal. Police later confirmed a man was found dead in the area. Magnet fishing has risen in popularity in recent years as people discovered the hobby on YouTube. title: couple buys 1970s milk float
story: Couple buys s milk float on eBay for £, and turns it into zero-waste mobile shopThe milk float, built in , had been retired from service, but it was still operational and was for sale for £, which prompted Lisa Jones and her husband Stephen Thomas to launch a new business from their homeLisa Jones and her husband Stephen Thomas started a zero-waste shop Image: Julie Kim PhotographyByEmma MagnusGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA couple bought a s milk float on eBay for £, before turning it into a zero-waste shop and travelling about in it. Lisa Jones and her husband Stephen Thomasspotted it on the auction site on a Sunday morning.I came across this milk float that was up for sale, Lisa told MyLondon.I turned to my husband and said: aposWhy donapost we just do it apos The float was built in , but it had been retired from service delivering milk and was still operational.It was for sale for £, on online auction site eBay.Before they could talk themselves out of it, Lisa had bought the milk float and the couple began the task of restoring it.  When it arrived, Thomo began the work before realising it was an enormous undertaking and would require the specialist help of restorer and repairer John Lenehan, based in Oxford. Itaposs like a milk float graveyard, said Lisa. She added: Thereaposs something quite eerie about it - but thereaposs nothing he doesnapost know about. Around a month later, it was ready - and it needed a name. Inspired by comedian Benny Hillaposs song, Ernie , the float was finally christened: Ernie. Itaposs not the fastest milk float in the West, it has to be said, says Lisa. But at  years old, Ernie is still running on his original battery - managing a modest  miles per hour and with the potential to travel for up to  miles before needing to be charged. Ernie can even make it up Muswell Hill in London, where the couple are based, but is often overtaken by pedestrians.  Lisa added: Thataposs all it needs, and itaposs been chugging on for  years, which I just find incredible. Ernieaposs purchase might have been spontaneous, but it was part of a grand plan Lisa and Thomo had been hatching throughout lockdown. Like lots of other people, my husband and I looked around us and started to reassess on so many levels - our lives, our working lives, wanting to do something dferent, wanting to do something which contributed and to get involved with our community a bit more, says Lisa. We looked around at what was happening to the planet while we were in lockdown and this sort of tentative attempt to heal itself...dolphins coming back to the Venetian harbour - all of this was incredible. It just goes to show that this is reversible we can change things. Thomo is an IT consultant and Lisa had been working as a food and drink PR and journalist, where sheaposd noticed a sht towards sustainability and independent, ethically-sourced products. They decided to combine their skills, with Lisa scaling back her work to concentrate on the project full-time.In August last year, they launched The Peopleaposs Pantry, a zero-waste mobile refill store and delivery service selling over  ethically-sourced products —including cereals, pasta, pulses, spices, cleaning products and household essentials— around eight North London postcodes.Lisa added: This is our small way of trying to be part of the solution. Thataposs all it needs, and itaposs been chugging on for  years, which I just find incredible, says Lisa.  She said: Itaposs in a small way, of course, but I think itaposs amazing - once you start doing something small like monitoring how much plastic you use, you suddenly become very aware of everything  that youaposre not doing. Hopefully itaposs going to be a stepping stone for people to reassess other areas of their lives as well - whether thataposs not flying as often, or getting on a bike rather than taking the car. With s Ernie and the companyaposs focus on community, The Peopleaposs Pantry trades on an element of nostalgia. Thereaposs a kind of nostalgia at the moment when the future is so crazy. I think weaposre all looking back to simpler, more wholesome, more manageable times, which has fuelled the vintage vibe.  She adds: I think people have been looking for ways to make a dference - but also ways to engage with each other. I think that was one of the very few positives to come out of the pandemic. Weaposve recognised how important community is and we started meeting our neighbours. Lisa is right. With the emergence of Mutual Aid and community groups during the pandemic, people began to connect with others around them in the first few months of the pandemic.According to a study by the ONS, over halfof adults said that friends, family and neighbours had offered to help themthey became unwell, rising to .% for over s.But,  months on, is this increased sense of community still catching on We hoped that the street visits would become this very social event and that neighbours would come and meet each other and put faces to WhatsApp feeds. And thataposs exactly whataposs happened, says Lisa. Itaposs something we werenapost entirely expecting.Five months into their venture, Lisa says that the reception to The Peopleaposs Pantry has been positive, with locals keen to contribute. Theyaposve seen innovative refillable solutions, including a woman who makes bags out of her sonaposs outgrown T-shirts, and a customer who has refilled an old bag of Sainsburyaposs basmati rice five times. Others have been willing to donate excess supplies - including, says Lisa, a customer with spare fertiliser from his wormery. Thataposs really uplting - itaposs exactly what we want it to be about. Ernie, meanwhile, has developed a following. Heaposs recognised in the street and was even sewn a Father Christmas hat by a neighbour. Heaposs developed a kind of personality of his own - heaposs like this comedy character with a serious soul, laughs Lisa. On a personal level, Lisa and Thomo have enjoyed working together. Thomo has built an e-commerce site for the company and has been working on an app. Actually, it was not a bad thing for our marriage, because you suddenly realise the strengths and skills that you donapost ordinarily see in each other because youaposre working in dferent fields...Iaposve been amazed at what heaposs able to do, she says. The couple have four children, with ying degrees of enthusiasm for their enterprise. Lisa says their eldest daughter recently told her she was pleased theyaposd launched the business because it had increased her own awareness and encouraged her to start conversations about sustainability at university. Their son is helping out with packing and deliveries - but insists on keeping some distance from Ernie. Theyaposre all really supportive. They love the idea - as long as they donapost have to be seen sitting in Ernie. Lisa feels that her career change was the right choice for her. I am pleased I made a change and Iaposm really enjoying it, she says. It does consume our week - but it doesnapost really matter when youaposre doing something that you enjoy. For the moment, Lisa and Thomo are concentrating on their own community, where they have lived for  years. But Lisa is not ruling out the possibility of more Ernies in future - coming, perhaps, to a community near you. title: devastated mums tribute beautiful girl
story: Devastated mums tribute to beautul girl, , killed in horror car crashThe grief-stricken mother of tragic teen Aaliyah Sedley Jones has paid an emotional tribute to her perfect and beautul girl who died at the scene of a horror crashThe heartbroken mum of tragic Aaliyah Sedley-Jones said her beloved daughter lit up any room Image: Avon and Somerset Constabulary   SWNSByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsThe grief-stricken mum of a tragic teen who died in a car crash is distraught after losing her perfect and beautul girl. Aaliyah Sedley-Jones, known as Lily, , could not be saved despite the best efforts of emergency responders and she died at the scene of the crash shortly after .pm on Wedesday, January . In a moving tribute released just days after her death, her mum says her only comfort is knowing she will never have to suffer the pain that her loved ones are feeling now. The tribute reads: Lily, you were taken just as your le was beginning and you were so excited for everything you had to look forward to. “You made the most of every single day of your le.  “You were my best friend, a breath of fresh air and you lit up any and every room you walked into. “You were so scared of losing anyone you loved and the only comfort I have is that at least now you will never have to suffer the pain everyone that knows you is feeling right now. “You genuinely were too perfect for this cruel world and the time where I can be with you again cannot come soon enough.  “Your four brothers and all of your family and friends will keep your memory alive as long as we all live. We will never stop talking about you as you were the most caring, considerate, loving, funny, most beautul girl and the time we had with you we will cherish forever. “Taken from us at the worst age of only  in a sudden tragic accident that will forever haunt us. “We were proud of you every moment of every day and we love you more than you could ever imagine my beautul Lily.” Specially-trained officers are supporting the family, who have asked for privacy. An investigation is underway into the circumstances leading up to the crash in Spring Hill, Weston-super-Mare.. In a statement released this afternoon, Somerset and Avon Police said: The family are being supported by a specially-trained family liaison officer and our thoughts are with them at this dreadful time. Please respect their privacy as they grieve. An investigation into the circumstances of the collision continues. title: four tips ditching alcohol entire
story: Four tips on ditching alcohol for an entire month and completing Dry JanuaryFrom saving lots of dosh to improving your health, there are lots of excellent reasons to take part in Dry January this year - here are some top tips to get you startedDry January can boost your physical and mental health Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsNew year, new you  Lots of us make New Yearaposs resolutions with every intention of keeping them - but our intentions can fall to the wayside as the month continues. After the year weaposve just endured, itaposs fair to say that many of us canapost be bothered to create a list of intentions this year. But health has been an important topic and for many of us, we might be thinking of ways we can improve.If youaposve decided to ditch alcohol for a month, congratulations.Itaposs a really positive change and with a few adjustments, you hopefully will power through this month unscathed. Should you need some inspiration, Alcohol Change UK has pulled together some top tips on how to complete Dry January during the pandemic.. Be prepared Preparation is key - especially in those early days when you might habitually go to open a beer or pour a glass of wine. Decide ahead of time how to deal with those cravings and be kind to yourself. Donapost stress about substituting alcohol with chocolate or sweets at first, especially in the first few days which are the hardest. The trick is to be prepared - make a list of reasons why you decided to take part in Dry January. Get rid of the booze in your house,that will help, and plan things to keep you busy. Decide what your coping mechanisms will beyou have some bad news or stress.  is certainly set to be stressful for the first few months, make sure you have some treats planned.  . Look after your mental health When we are stressed, itaposs easy to reach for booze as a coping mechanism. To make sure youaposre less tempted, make sure youaposre protecting your mental health. Itaposs important to eat healthily, get outside once a daypossible and schedule time to talk to friends and family. Not relying on booze will help you find healthier coping mechanisms to deal with the dficult feelings. . Find new ways to relax As you might find yourself with empty time on your hands, make sure theyaposre not left idle for a long time. Try and find some new hobbies - and treat yourself to some nice alternatives to booze, such as a posh soft drink or tea. . Be kind to yourself Itaposs hard to break habits and itaposs undeniably tough times for all of us anyway. Alcohol Change UK advises: One of the key things we want you to remember this Dry January is to be gentle with yourself. We’ve all been through a lot this past year, so don’t feel disheartened when change doesn’t come as easily as you had hoped. You can definitely do this, and we’re right by your side.For more advice, check out more top tips here. Are you taking part in dry January Let us know in the comments below. title: inside abandoned london underground station
story: Inside abandoned London Underground station you can hire out for £, an hourThere are  abandoned Tube stations in London with some converted into flats, but many are disused and provide an ideal environment for filming below ground where crews cannot be disturbedAldwych Underground station Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByErica BuistGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA look inside an abandoned tube station has been revealed and itaposs yours to hire out for £ an hour.Any film or TV series set in London is likely to feature the Underground at some point.And many productions may want to use a modern-day Tube setting, but others will want something darker or even abandoned - like Aldwych Underground station, which lies desolate. There are  abandoned Tube stations, with some converted into flats, but many are disused and provide an ideal environment for filming. This makes them an ideal location for film crew seeking somewhere more dingy.But MyLondon says the “exclusive spaces” are not open to the public and will really cost anyone who wants to hire them. Any film or TV series will feature the Underground at some point, but plenty of filmmakers want something darker or abandoned. London has at least  abandoned Tube stations, and while some have been converted into flats or even an escape room, many of them really are abandoned and disused. This makes them the perfect location for film producers seeking somewhere discreet to film.  But hiring the “exclusive spaces” that the public cannot access will really cost you. We have several exclusive areas,” says the TfL guide, “Aldwych, Bankand Charing Cross.” Aldwych “has the most flexible access and does not have any restrictions with timings” - which makes sense, since it was closed in . Many films and TV series have been shot there, including Sherlock, Atonement, V for Vendetta and Superman IV: The Quest for Peace.  One  on the Waterloo  City Line branch of Bank station can be made available - as it was to the crew of the film Sliding Doors - plus a ticket hallyou want to film on a Sunday, as it’s closed. Since the Jubilee line stopped its service to Charing Cross in , the two disused s and three escalators are “completely segregated from the rest of the station” and, for an extra charge, bulky equipment can be brought to the station during off-peak hours on a specially-organised train.  Charing Cross has been used for films such as  Weeks Later and Skyfall and others such as Killing Eve and Spooks. But hiring an underground station is not cheap and will cost film producers who want to. “Charges for exclusive areas currently start at £, an hourfor the station or £, an hourwith the additional use of your own train.” But an abandoned Tube station where people wonapost be inconvenienced could cost that much per hour. Locations would rather you didn’t use their electricity. The Film Office says they generally request that film crews use battery-operated equipment as they operate on a dferent voltage system to the standard domestic set-up and connections to their power supply must be supervised by a specialist electrician.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON London NewsLondon Underground" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: kate middleton coming own ready
story: Secrets of photo that prove Kate Middletons coming into her own and ready to be queenRoyal commentator Ingrid Seward says people see Kate Middleton as the perfect queen, young and beautul. However, she adds the Duchess of Cambridge will be keen not to upstage CamillaKate Middleton photographed to mark her th birthday Image: Paolo Roversi Kensington PalaceByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments While the photo that snatched the headlines this weekend was dynamic Kate at  in sizzling red, it was the subtler profile shot in white which spoke a thousand words about the Duchess’s burgeoning royal status.While her profile is delicate, her expression soft as the tulle of her dress, and her curls whimsically blowing in the breeze of a wind machine, there is a strength about the romantic photograph which shouts queen-in-waiting. The pose is far from new. It is one which has been used repeatedly down the decades to capture a young princess or duchess coming of age, their elegant footing firm on the path to queendom. As well as by female monarchs well established in their reign. Queen Victoria, Queen Mary, the Queen Mother, Princess Margaret, Diana, even Princess Grace of Monaco, not to mention our current Queen, have struck similar poses. The combination of romanticism and regality is recognisable straightaway as Kate holds a mirror to former eras. Royal commentator Ingrid Seward explains: “In this image I think you see a nod to Kate rising up the ranks. People look at her and see the perfect queen, young and beautul. “It evokes an image of the Queen as a young woman and even conjures up historically a Boadicea, strong, yet feminine - femininity yet strength. “That idealised image of a young queen, serene, in control and poised.” She adds: “Kate is coming into her own. She is genuinely involved in her charity work, which will be her legacy. “We have seen her in the peacemaker role between William and Harry, we saw her at the carol concert in Westminster stepping confidently into the spotlight, she is no longer a clothes horse, there is a strength there now. “We can see Kate stepping up a level, the coming of a queen in waiting, and I think she is more ready to fill those shoes.” But she stresses the Duchess will no doubt feel embarrassed by the attention on her position. She’s been in The Firm long enough to know she must not overstep the mark. “Prince Charles is not even King yet and the Royals are very careful about not upstaging each other. Kate will be keen not to upstage Camilla,” says Ingrid. “She is aware of hierarchy and that it is Camilla’s turn. “But she is a wonderful advert for the monarchy, especially globally, and people will see her as the perfect queen.”  Platinum puddings By Tyrese ChinDenCoy What better way to celebrate the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee this year than with cake  Her Maj has decreed a Royal Bake Off, asking the nation to come up with a pud we can all raise a spoon to. Fortnum and Mason and The Big Jubilee Lunch invite Britain’s bakers, aged eight and above, to create a dish that can be replicated across the country to celebrate the -year milestone.  Five finalists will have the chance to bake their dishes at Fortnum’s store in Piccadilly to be judged by Dame Mary Berry, palace head chef Mark Flanagan and Masterchef list Monica Galetti. Why not take some inspiration from Royal favourites, old or new  From Prince William’s chocolate biscuit cake to Henry the VIII’s favourite red wine and ginger jelly or Queen Victoria’s famous Victoria Sponge, they’re a family of sweet tooths. Henry VIII Favourite Food: Jelly Hippocras. Henry VIII was a large man and would often have over  freshly cooked dishes served for him every day. He loved his red wine and even built two fountains which spouted hundreds of gallons of the stuff for him and his courtiers to enjoy everyday. Alongside it, Henry particularly liked this jelly which included wine, ginger and cinnamon. Victoria I Favourite Food: Victoria Sponge Cake Queen Victoria was someone who enjoyed eating and was said to have had a hearty appetite. She enjoyed sweet foods from ice-creams to pastries, and cake so much that the Victoria Sponge was named after her. Duchess Kate Favourite Food: Sticky Toffee Pudding Kate’s fav foods reportedly include sushi and Italian - the latter because it’s easy to cook with ther kids and let them get their hands messy. But when it comes to favourite puds it’s a spongy Sticky Toffee Pudding. Prince William Favourite Food: Chocolate biscuit cake The Duke is a big fan of chocolate biscuit cakes, so much so the cake was served at his wedding. William’s fondness for the cake apparently comes from a specic recipe which he learnt from his grandmother, the Queen. news uk-news kate-middleton-dressed-up-cheryl-"Kate Middleton releases photographs to mark th birthdayByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments She may have celebrated her milestone th birthday - but there was no big party for the Duchess of Cambridge. She is thought to have spent the day of her birthday yesterday privately with her family having a low-key celebration.And this could have suited Kate perfectly, who even in her university days wasnapost one for tearing the town up and could apparently nurse one glass of wine all night. In her book Kate: The Future Queen, royal author Katie Nicholl speaks to an unnamed friend, who joined Kate on a gap year trip to Italy. The friend claimed: Sheaposd get giggly and silly after a few glasses, so then she would stop.  She was never interested in getting really drunk. She wasnapost really a party girl. She wasnapost uptight or boring, she was really fun and lovely, but going out and getting wasted wasnapost really her thing.But one party she wasnapost able to get out of having was her hen party in , shortly before marrying Prince William.Kateaposs sister Pippa reportedly organised a private do at the house of a friend, with the guest list kept to a minimum.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.And it appears Kate let her hair down by donning a racy outfit and channelling popstar Cheryl by singing and dancing to her hit song Fight For This Love. Writing in her autobiography, Cheryl revealed how she bumped into William backstage at the Queenaposs Diamond Jubilee concert in  and he cheekily joked: “Did you know you’ve got a bit of competition ” According to Cheryl, the couple started giggling before Kate admitted sheaposd performed the staraposs  hit at her hen do.  The former Girls Aloud star writes in her autobiography Cheryl My Story: Kate confessed that she dressed up as me on her hen night, in a bodysuit and split trousers, and sang Fight For This Love. She even learnt the dance routine and was step-perfect by all accounts, as her sister Pippa and brother James also came over and told me all about it.However, despite missing out on a big birthday bash, Kate could have a joint th party with William later in the year.  The Queen is expected to throw William a party for his own th in June, with Windsor Castle or Sandringham among the likely venues.Similar lavish bashes have previously been thrown to jointly celebrate signicant birthdays of several members of the family at the same time. Back in June , a huge do was held at Windsor to celebrate Prince Andrew’s th birthday, Princess Anne’s th, Princess Margaret’s th and William’s th. Ingrid Seward, editor-in-chief of Majesty Magazine, said she expects the Queen will play a major role in the planning of the party for William. Ingrid said: “The Queen is tremendously fond of enjoying such occasions and this would be no dferent. “There’s a lot to look forward to in her Platinum Jubilee year, and with both William and Kate turning  it’s an extra excuse to celebrate. “This is a pretty big one for the Cambridges so it should be quite the party.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Kate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeCherylPrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: labrador chihuahua five most least
story: From Labrador to Chihuahua: The five most and least active dog breeds - see full listLabradors and golden retrievers will thank you for their exercise more than a Chihuahua will - so here are the best breeds for those looking for a training buddyStock image: some dog breeds are more likely to be up for a km run than others Image: GettyByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Jan | commentsIf your New Years’ resolution was to ‘get fit’, ‘walk more’ or ‘train for a marathon’, then why not get the dog involved too  For some of us, the thought of leaving the house to lt weights or run on a treadmill at the gym is not overly appealing. Most dogs, however, love dashing out for some good exercise, and only need to hear ‘do you wanna go for a…’ before bounding around in excitement. Dogs can help to maintain a healthy lestyle, heading out on daily walks and adventures - but some are more up to it than others.Andyou’re considering getting a dog to be your training buddy and running partner, it’s important to do your research and say, not get bichon frise.That said, while all dog breeds need exercise, some require more physical activity than others, andViovethave pulled together a list of the most physically active dogs who will relish the opportunity to join you on your outdoor activities.Here are five of the most active breeds that love nothing more than a good run or two: Labrador Golden Retriever  Hands down one of the most loved and popular dog breeds, the Labrador is a very friendly dog that requires a lot of physical activity. Alongside frequent walks by the beach or in the countryside, it also enjoys playing fetch and splashing about in water. Similarly, golden retrievers have a soft spot for swimming too. Both very active and clever, they can easily engage in strenuous activities – so make sure you make allowances for that. Dalmatian  Dalmatians are great exercisers and ideally need two hours of physical activity per day. Once used as ‘carriage dogs’ to guard the passengers and reassure the horses in the stable at night, running long distances is in their DNA. While not the quickest of sprinters, Dalmatians have tonnes of energy. They will truly benefit from long trots in the countryside and mentally stimulating activities. Siberian husky  There is no hiding that it is dficult to tire out a Siberian husky. Usually bred to pull heavy sledges and travel long distances in challenging climates, this dog breed has buckets of energy. A Siberian husky that is not adequately exercised may cause some mischief in the home. Therefore, it is important to schedule a daily two-hour walk or run and allow them to enjoy some satisfactory physical activity. German shepherd  Bright, strong and obedient, it’s no wonder that German shepherds are often used in police forces. They are very loyal companions that are not well-suited to apartment le and require at least a couple of hours of exercise every day. Get them stuck in engaging and physically demanding activities – you will soon discover that they are great fun to both train and go on adventures with. Border collie  If you ever asked a class of dog breeds whether they enjoy working, border collies will be the first to raise their paw. Often involved in sheep herding, these pooches are always on the move and are quick to complete their tasks. To keep them physically and mentally stimulated, make sure to provide them with lots of exercise. With all that energy, it takes quite a while to wear them out. The five least active breeds Some dogs simply weren’t bred to be workers or long distance runners, andthis kind of dog suits your lestyle better, then here are some suitable canine candidates. Maltese  They may well be intelligent and energetic dogs, but the little Maltese is more than satisfied with a -minute walk down the road or a short run in the garden. Indeed, it is plenty of exercise for this adorable dog breed. Once the pampered babies of noble ladies of the Roman Empire, it is no surprise that the little Maltese enjoys relaxing in its cosy abode. Chihuahua  Tiny and loud, chihuahuas are small dogs with big attitudes and huge personalities. Weighing just under three kilos on average, it goes without saying that they do not need hours and hours of physical activity. A stroll in the park will do the job, and they will then be ready to head back home without any complaints. Bichon frise  More than happy to sit on your lap and be stroked all day, the cloud-like bichon frise is the perfect companion for elderly owners or dog lovers with mobility issues. A short, half-an-hour daily walk is all the bichon frise asks for, and will quite gladly spend the rest of their day grooming its fluffy curls. Chow Chow  Famous for their friendly and wrinkly face, the Chow Chow is the perfect cuddly companion for a night in. They are also good dogs for people who have very busy routines, as they only require one walk per day to keep in shape and to socialise with fellow pooches. Moreover, they tend to be quite independent. This means that you do not need to stimulate them as much to keep them entertained. King Charles Spaniel  Possibly one of the most regal-looking breed dogs out there, King Charles spaniels enjoy sitting on their throne most of the time. Due to their generally relaxed nature, there is no need to take them on kilometric walks – short strolls will do just fine. That said, they also love some playtime and being around both adults and children. Ultimately, it is vital to always find time for your dogs to engage in some deserved physical activities. Some friendly companions require lots of exercise others, not so much. With this list at hand, you will be able to discover what dog breed suits your lestyle best without compromising on their all-important daily ‘walkies’. title: man detained public after trying
story: Man detained by public after trying to lead girl, , from family in pubCheshire Police say a -year-old man approached the girl in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire before he was challenged by a parent and othersA -year-old man approached the four-year-old child in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire, police said Image: MEN MediaByTom DuffyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A man was detained by the public after allegedly trying to lead a young girl from a pub. A -year-old man approached the four-year-old child in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire and tried to lead her away, police said. A parent then challenged the man and other members quickly detained him at the scene. It happened at about pm on Saturday and police have since arrested a -year-old man on suspicion of child abduction. He remains in custody. A spokesperson for Cheshire Constabulary said: Police have arrested a -year-old man from Middlewich following a report of a child abduction in Middlewich.  At pm on Saturday  January a man approached a four-year-old girl in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Lewin Street, Middlewich and tried to lead her away. He was challenged by a parent, and members of the public detained him outside the pub to prevent him from leaving the area. The girl was thankfully physically unharmed by the incident. Police subsequently arrested a man on suspicion of child abduction. He remains in custody. Chief Inspector Claire Jesson said: “While this was very concerning incident, this was isolated and the suspect was swtly arrested. “I’d like to thank those who intervened and prevented the suspect from leaving the area. “We have increased patrols to provide reassurance and the family are being supported by officers.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Cheshire Police" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
