title: reminder to register little ones for p1
story: This year#s primary one registration will take place online, via the council website, due to Covid- restrictions.To register your child for this year#s intake, or for further information, including how to make a placing request and how to request early entry to primary school, visit www.argyll-bute.gov.uk forms school-registrationAnyone unable to access the online registration form can call their local school during the week beginning January  .

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: new-netflix-film-starring-vanessa-hudgens-features-east-lothian-beauty-spot
story: The Princess Switch : Romancing the Star was filmed in Scotland at the end of , with the High School Musical star filming on the Gosford Estate, near Longniddry, before Christmas last year.Cast and crew were also spotted in Midlothian, at Newbattle Abbey College in Dalkeith.Hudgens plays three roles, including as Fiona Pembroke and Queen Margaret.Filming took place on private estates to keep cast and crew away from congested areas.The film, directed by Mike Rohl, also stars Nick Sagar and Remy Hii.

title: plans-knock-replace-petrol-station-old-craighall
story: The Motor Fuel Grouphas applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission to knock down the petrol station already there and replace it with “an enhanced roadside services offer” which would be open  hours as part of the redevelopment of Monktonhall Services.A drive-thru coffee shop will also be built on the site as part of a separate plan which has received the green light from the council.The former Travelodge building has been demolished and a new hotel is no longer planned.The new development would have an increased focus on HGVs, including a standalone refuelling area for trucks and lorries comprising two pumps.There would be a secure parking and rest area for HGVs, complete with a shower and toilet block for drivers’ use.This facilities block would be formed from a former tourist information block on the site.This parking area would have space for up to  large vehicles.A new petrol filling station – including a retail kiosk and forecourt including six pumps, three jetwash bays and two air vac water bays – is a key part of the plans.Eight charging points for electric vehicles would also be created.There would also be a bin store, car and cycle parking and landscaping, and an internal road layout is planned at the site which is located at the junction of the A, Edinburgh City bypass and B.A supporting statement, issued on behalf of the company by chartered surveyors and property consultants Graham + Sibbald LLP, said: “The proposal will redevelop the established services to modernise the existing offer on-site.“The enhanced facilities are intended to react to current and predicted trends in the roadside industry such as increased demand for EV charging points and the provision of a safe place for HGV drivers to rest and refuel to support the haulage and logistics sector.“In this way, the site will develop economic resiliency and be future-proofed for these coming trends.”And it added: “The principal vehicle access to the site will remain in its current location, where vehicles access the site from the southeast corner via the internal one-way system. Site egress will remain at the roundabout to the northwest of the site.“This internal road layout will also be used by vehicles exiting from the adjacent site to the east that has recently received planning consent for a drive-thru coffee shop.”The coffee shop, with a floor area of  square metres, would provide hot food and drinks and would have drive-thru facilities, as well as outdoor and indoor seating areas, and toilets.Open seven days a week from am to pm, it is earmarked to provide employment for  to  full-time staff.Thirty-eight parking spaces, four of which would provide electric vehicle charging points, and a motorcycle parking area are planned.Graham Wilson MRICS, MFG’s property director, said: “Motor Fuel Group is excited about the proposed development of our BP station at Monktonhall.“Improved parking facilities for HGV drivers, shop and ‘food to go’ offerings for customers and the addition of an EV charging hub with eight ultra-rapid chargers will be a great asset to the local area.“As soon as final planning approval is given, we will start the redevelopment [we are] hoping to complete in .”Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, said of the plans: “I welcome the proposals to replace the current facility and the job creation which comes alongside that.“We know that HGVs are vital for our supply chain and the dedicated rest space for HGV trucks in this area will assist the sector greatly in many respects.”Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, said: “The current site is looking rather dilapidated and a replacement can only be of benefit.“The jobs will be an additional benefit but hauliers and travellers will welcome it.”

title: 10-school-classrooms-go-virtual-covid-cases-rise-east-lothian
story: Schools opened their doors following the festive break but staff shortages, due to Covid-, meant some classrooms were empty.Wallyford Primary School and Pencaitland Primary School were among schools with classes that did notin person, while a class at Ross High School ASN base was also learning remotely from home.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: “The majority of our schools have ed to in-person teaching.“However, due to the impacts of teaching staff self-isolating, a number of pupils are temporarily learning at home.“This mainly affects children in primary school and a small number of our specialist communication bases.“All of our schools have contingency plans in place so they can make the move to remote learning quickly and are grateful for the support of their families. Support has been given to families throughout earlier lockdowns and in any subsequent temporary periods of remote learning to ensure all learners have the equipment they need to access materials.“The challenges caused by COVID- continue to be signicant.“It is important that everyone plays their part and follows the important measures that will limit the spread of COVID- in society so that essential services, including education, health and social care, can continue to operate.”Meanwhile, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed the self-isolation period for people with Covid- in Scotland has been cut from ten to seven days, in a move following the approach of other devolved nations.The First Minister concluded her first Covid announcement of the new year by saying: “This phase of the pandemic is possibly the most challenging so far.“The most infectious iant so far is creating a volume of cases that, notwithstanding its possibly reduced severity, still has the potential to overwhelm us.“And two years in, the kind of measures that have helped us control transmission in past phases are becoming less tolerable and causing more harm.”This comes as East Lothian hits a record high number of Covid figures.Between December   and January  , , cases of the virus were recorded, giving a seven-day positive rate per , people of .The county’s rate remains the lowest in the Lothians – Midlothian’s current seven-day positive rate per , people is ,., West Lothian’s ,. and Edinburgh’s ,..In the county, Wallyford Whitecraig recorded the most cases in the last seven days , giving it a Haddington Corn Exchange or Musselburgh Primary Care Centre for appointments.Drop-in appointments are only available at Haddington Corn Exchange.All iniduals with a scheduled appointment at East title: vandals-strike-historic-estate-leaving-25-panes-glass-shattered
story: Over  panes of historic glass, some of which was originally installed when the Palladian-style house was built in , were shattered by vandals on January  and .A post published by Newhailes House and Gardens read: "We are really sad to report that on January  and , Newhailes House suffered at the hands of some mindless vandals."Over  panes of historic glass, some of which was original, have been smashed."The cost to our charity of repairing this damage is vast as is the cost of the additional security we are putting in place until our CCTV is installed."Image: Newhailes House and Gardens FacebookNewhailes, which is run by the National Trust for Scotland, has asked regular visitors or anyone with information to contact Police Scotland quoting the reference number .A number of Facebook users and visitors expressed their sadness over the targeted vandalism.One social media user said: "So sorry to hear about this. Heart breaking for everyone who cares for this beautul house."Another added: "Words fail me that these disgusting apologies for humans can get away with this. I do hope someone somewhere can help. So sad that this has happened."Image: Newhailes House and Gardens Facebook

title: short-courses-offer-queen-margaret-university-help-recovery-pandemic
story: They have been funded by the Scottish Government and Scottish Funding Council’s Upskilling Fund to support Scotland’s recovery from the Covid- pandemic.Available from this month and with no need to have qualications in the subject area, free places are available to anyone living in Scotland over the age of  who is either: unemployed, at risk of redundancy or in a job that is under threat because of Covid- or the economic impact of EU exit self-employed and working within the creative and cultural industries or hospitality, tourism and events sector employed by a Scottish arts, cultural, education, hospitality, tourism or events organisation or employed by a Scottish charity or social enterprise whose work contributes to Scotland’s recovery from the Covid- pandemic.The credit-bearing courses will be taught via a blend of online lectures, self-directed learning and in-person class-based practical workshops delivered at the university’s Musselburgh campus.Professor David Stevenson, dean of arts, social sciences and management at QMU, said: “We are delighted to be able to offer this range of new short courses.“The free places provided by the Scottish Funding Council’s Upskilling fund mean that we can support those working in some of the sectors where employment was most signicantly impacted by the pandemic to develop new skills and enhance their employability.”The courses are: Introduction to Film Education, which starts in FebruaryEvaluating Arts and Cultural Projects, which starts in JanuaryFundraising, Development and Finance which starts in JanuaryEntrepreneurial Finance which starts in Marchand Sustainable and Safe Event Management, which starts in March . Further short courses with a spring  start date will be announced in due course.For more information, go to qmu.ac.uk study-here continuing-professional-development-cpd-courses arts-social-sciences-and-management-short-courses

title: end-era-rbg-fruits-macmerry-shuts-55-years
story: RBG Fruits has gone from open-air markets across southern and central Scotland to being a familiar sight at the heart of Macmerry.It was founded  years ago by Gabriel Noonan, whose daughter Gabriella has been involved in the business for  years.The curtain came down on trading on Christmas Eve, with Gabriella overwhelmed by the many kind words received from members of the public.Just before that day, she told the Courier: “We have people drive to us from all over. We have a man who comes from Bathgate, and we have someone come from Bonnyrigg.“We love our customers and get time to blether, whereas nowadays everybody is far too busy.“It is very strange thinking about the last day. The more I am talking about it now, the more I am getting emotional.“It comes at a time where things change. People change and it is just time to see what is out there time for something new – it is scary for me but it is all I have known.”Selling a wide range of fruit and vegetables, the business has grown to include dog food and dog beds.Gabriel visited fruit markets across the country, from Gretna, Dumfries and Annan in Dumfries and Galloway, to Bathgate, Falkirk and East Fortune.It has become a real family business, with -year-old Gabriella joined by cousin John O’Connell, who has been a fixture for  years, and sister Shelly Horne, whom she would be “lost without”.Gabriella, whose mum Rose has also been at the heart of the business, said she “loved” both her job and customers, despite the regular early rises. A book was set up at the business for customers to leave kind words ahead of its closure.Now, Gabriella is looking ahead to what the future holds.She said: “I would like to learn a language, go back to university.“I would like to have a few lie-ins.“The other thing is the cold – standing out in the cold, wind and rain when we did the market.”Roofing firm Raymond Mills is taking over their premises on Macmerry’s Westbank Road.Councillor Colin McGinn, who represents the Tranent Wallyford and Macmerry ward, described the closure as “a big loss to the community”.He said: “It is a long-standing business and it has made a real impact on Macmerry and East Lothian for thatof time.“They were actually great in relation to working with the community and making sure people got what they wanted.”

title: popular-youth-facility-thespace-find-new-home-dunbar
story: theSPACE, which featured a large skate park, music practice rooms, a cafe and more, left its home at the old Ben Sayers Factory in the town in March  at the end of its lease and efforts to find a new home for the well-used facility proved unsuccessful.However, now plans for a new thespaceDunbar, potentially featuring a skatepark, ten-pin bowling space, bouldering climbing wall, and cinema and performance space, are among the options being weighed up for a major development on the outskirts of the town.Proposals for the .-acre DunBear Park site to the rear of the town’s Asda store are continuing to be drawn up.Already, Lidl and BM have confirmed their hopes to move to the town and create  jobs.At the same time, a new youth facility was proposed for the site, which is sandwiched by the A and the East Coast Main Line.Now, thespaceScotland CIC has confirmed they are in active discussions with Hallhill Developments Ltd, which is at the heart of developing the site, on a shared ambition to create thespaceDunbar at DunBear Park.Adrian Girling, of thespaceScotland CIC, told the Courier a range of options were being considered.He said: “We are delighted to be working in partnership with Ken Ross and with Hallhill Developments Ltd on exciting plans for DunBear Park. We want to create a groundbreaking youth-powered social enterprise that has facilities and opportunities for the whole community.“We can’t wait to work alongside young people, investing in and nurturing the power and potential of youth in our communities to make this ambitious plan happen.”Mr Girling was keen to secure “an exclusivity agreement” on a site as part of phase two of the DunBear Park development.That will allow the group to secure the necessary money and planning permission for the site.According to Mr Girling, thespaceDunbar will be a vibrant and sustainable youth and community hub providing facilities, opportunities and spaces for young people, adults, children and families. Promoting active, social and creative lives will help build strong and erse communities around shared interests and passions.thespaceDunbar could provide the following:Mr Girling added: “thespaceDunbar will provide young people with employment opportunities trade, hospitality and management apprenticeships volunteering opportunities work-based training programmes partnerships to support school-based qualications short and long term work experience placements transition support skills training for youth groups and much more.”Drawings included with East Lothian Council for DunBear Park show proposals for two drive-thru restaurants, which would be created beside the already-established McDonald’s drive-thru restaurant.Also included in the masterplan is space for an “electric transport hub” and “energy centre”.Further retail units are planned, with space also for an extension to Dunbar Garden Centre, and other employment areas.The proposals for BM and Lidl remain with the council’s planning department.

title: two-members-dunbar-lifeboat-crew-pass-coxswains
story: Kevan Jamieson and Henry Weaver passed a gruelling assessment on December  with flying colours.They are now qualied to take charge of the Trent class ALB John Neville Taylor.Kevan, , who joined the crew six years ago and is also an ALB mechanic, said: “It’s been a tough couple of years’ training, but I’m looking forward to the challenge of being ALB coxswain.“We couldn’t have done it without the help of our crew and, in particular, existing coxswains Gary Fairbairn and Gordon Mackay.”Kevan, who is married to Rhona and dad to Jenner and Archie, recently retired from his previous job but, as well as being a mainstay of the ALB crew, also drives articulated lorries delivering cement for Tarmac.Henry, , who is the RNLI’s area lesaving manager for the north-east of Scotland, was similarly pleased.He said: “It was quite a stressful assessment.“Everything was thrown at us, like a man over board and an engine fire.”Henry, who is married to Sarah and dad to -month-old Reuben, has been with the RNLI for nine years.He added: “It’s been a long process but I’m grateful to the support I’ve received, both from Sarah at home and from the crew.”Gary Fairbairn, Dunbar’s full-time coxswain, added: “Congratulations to both.”

title: young-dancers-enjoy-christmas-showcase-brunton
story: Students at the Alpha Dance Academy, they attend classes at The Fraser Centre in Tranent and Musselburgh Congregational Church Hall, as well as at Joppa, Danderhall and Bonnyrigg.The showcase, which is enjoyed by family and friends, is an annual event but it has been two years since the last show due to the Covid- pandemic.The dancers, aged two to , performed ballet, tap, jazz, hip hop and cheerleading.“They all absolutely loved it,” said Lorraine Frankitti, principal teacher.

title: gifford-lunch-club-meets-last-first-time-two-years
story: Due to Covid-, the group was unable to invite a special guest to the event but the  diners enjoyed a quiz devised by Joe Clark and each went home with a Christmas gt.The group thanked Gford Horticultural Society for its support, the volunteers who made the event possible, the Tweeddale staff, and the kind donor who paid for everybody’s first drink.

title: hibs-hero-pat-stanton-pays-visit-ross-high-school
story: Pat Stanton, a Scottish former football player and manager, spent most of his professional career with Hibernian FC.He made a special visit to speak with pupils at the school on December .Stanton is the great-great nephew of Michael Whelahan – a founder of Hibernian and its first captain – and the great-nephew of Hibs centre forward James Hendren.In recent weeks, pupils at the school also enjoyed a visit from Hibernian Ladies captain Joelle Murray.The visits allowed Hibs Class+ participants to ask questions about a range of aspects associated with the club, resulting in interesting stories and information being shared with the groups.In late April , the Hibernian Community Foundation undertook a survey of young people who had been engaging with their programmes before the Covid- pandemic to identy and establish how these young people felt lockdown and isolating had impacted on them and their general health and wellbeing.The survey highlighted that young people had real concerns centred around worsening mental wellbeing, increased loneliness and isolation.Using this data as a baseline and impetus, the club designed Hibs Class+, an innovative programme providing an alternative curriculum to S and S pupils at Ross High School aimed at improving health and wellbeing outcomes.Elaine McKay, social studies teacher, and Kerry-Anne Dougan, music teacher and lelong Hibs fan, are responsible for delivering the Hibs Class+ and Hibs Masterclass at the school.On Thursdays, Sue McLernon and Andrew Cheshire from the Hibernian Community Foundation attend the school to help deliver the programmes.

title: chance-meet-team-working-preston-tower-drop-in-session
story: People interested in learning about the repairs to the Prestonpans landmark are invited along to the lunchtime session from .pm to .pm to meet the team working on the tower.A number of improvements have been planned at the late medieval tower house and nearby doocot. Restoration is focused on improving access and encouraging people to visit, while contributing to local regeneration.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-january-3-7-1997-1972-1922
story: years ago‘CHRISTMAS tragedy averted after bomb found on beach’ was a headline on the front page of the East Lothian Courier on January , .A  pound practice bomb found on Tyninghame beach was detonated by Royal Navy bomb disposal experts on Monday, averting a potential tragedy.The Christmas cracker with a dference, packed with half a pound of explosive, was discovered on Sunday morning by local man, John Eldridge, out walking his dog.John, , of St Baldred’s Road, North Berwick, found the bomb lying in the sand but did not immediately recognise what it was or the danger it posed to le and limb.“It was around am when I saw this unusual object lying in the sand,” he said.“I was not sure what it was and so walked around it a couple of times to try and get a closer look.“Up close there was no doubt that it was a bomb.” years ago‘OLDEST trader ready to retire’ reported the East Lothian Courier on January , .When Mr Arnot Hepburn’s provisions shop in the West End of North Berwick closes down in a few weeks, it will mark the end of an era.Mr Hepburn, who is now over  years of age, is and has been in North Berwick for  years, and is the oldest trader still working in the town.Along with the late Mr Coventry, he helped to form the North Berwick Community Association.A keen churchman, Mr Hepburn is senior Elder of the Abbey Church and was Preses of the Board of Management for several years. years agoTHE tale of a ‘provincial Dick Whittington’ was told in The Haddingtonshire Courier of January , .The will of the late Miss Adelaide Watt of Speke Hall, near Liverpool, and of Spott estate, near Dunbar, recalls the romantic origin of the Watt family.Her estate was valued at £,.The founder, Richard Watt, uncle of Miss Watt’s father, was described as a “provincial Dick Whittington”.Born in Lancashire of humble parentage, he was employed by a cow keeper named Dimoke to drive a one-horse chaise.His master placed him at an evening school, and, later, he went to sea.Reaching the West Indies, he remained there and engaged in business, eventually amassing a vast fortune.Forty years after he left this country, he ed, inquired after the Dimoke family, and, finding two maiden sisters alive, settled £ a year on each of them for le.

title: lidl-shoppers-win-25-000-weekly-shop---find
story: The supermarket has launched a Stamp Card feature which could see shoppers who visit stores between January  – February  be in with the chance of winning £,.This is available to people who already have the Lidl Plus App and customers who download it now. Shoppers will be able to earn a stamp every time they shop, earning one stamp when they spend more than £ and scan their Lidl Plus card.You will need  stamps to enter the prize draw." alt"East Lothian Courier: Lidl Plus app " class"editor-image"Lidl Plus appOnce you have obtained  stamps, shoppers can win one of  prizes, including the main prize of £, cash.Runner up prizes include a Mini Electric car or one of three family Jet holidays.To be in with a chance of winning these amazing prizes, shoppers simply need to download the Lidl Plus app and follow the on-screen instructions.As well as the chance to win these prizes, Lidl Plus customers can use the app to get access to exclusive discounts, view digital receipts and browse weekly leaflets and seasonal magazines.Lidl Plus is available to download from the App Store and Google Play.

title: tims-tales-cross-aberlady
story: He is chair and a founder member of the Aberlady Conservation and History Society, and I wanted to chat with him about the story behind the replica of the Anglo-Saxon Christian cross which stands in the small memorial garden close to the village kirk.The story begins in , when a fragment of an early Christian cross was discovered in the garden wall of the former manse, just east of the kirk. This original fragment is now in the National Museum of Scotland but its discovery suggested something very signicant about Aberlady’s early history.The design on the fragment was similar to the artwork of the Lindisfarne Gospels, an illuminated manuscript made on Holy Island and completed around AD. This Gospel book is a priceless national treasure, probably created by Eadfrith, the Bishop of Lindisfarne.Ian has a passion for history, especially early Medieval history in the time before Scotland, and so the cross fragment had always fascinated him. The dimensions of the cross fragment suggested that, before it was broken, it would have stood about five metres tall.“A large cross with this level of ornate carving would only be commissioned and erected at a place of some importance,” he told me.“The Celtic Church was widening and deepening its influence and its leaders now had the ear of kings. Royal endowments of land and wealth to the Church and rewards to loyal and battle-hardened thanes co-existed. This was very much a time of devout holy men and warlords. It was such an exciting piece of evidence of Aberlady’s early history.”Ian explained that a cross of similar date and style at Abercorn in West Lothian was very probably carved by the same person, or team of masons, and gave an idea of what the rest of the cross at Aberlady might have looked like. Intriguingly, there were three fragments of that cross.When he told me this, my thoughts wandered for a moment. Here we were, having a wee drink in a pub, talking about a craftsman, or group of craftsmen, whose skill and creativity has been preserved for well over a thousand years, and yet we know nothing about them, not even their names. I raised a glass to them and the countless thousands of skilled stonemasons, joiners, builders and artists of all kinds who really did build our historic monuments, but whom history almost never credits.But, I thought, at least we know who made the beautul recreation: Barry Grove, who also carved the reconstruction of the Pictish cross-slab at Hilton of Cadboll – and he used the same simple tools and techniques that would have been used by those earlier stone masons. The cross was unveiled in Aberlady’s Memorial Garden on December , .Ian then told me of the lost ecclesiastical settlement of Pefferham. He explained that there was a medieval document called Historia Regum, meaning History of the Kings. It was written in the th century and is usually credited to Symeon of Durham. This document listed all the main churches of existence in the Northumbrian diocese of St Cuthbert during the ninth and th centuries AD. Aberlady would have been part of this diocese.“Each of the important churches of the diocese, including Melrose, Abercorn, Edinburgh, Auldhame and Tyninghame, are identied in a clockwise direction in the Historia Regum,” Ian explained. “But there is one church mentioned in that document that is lost in time and seems to have vanished from both maps and memories. It was known as Pefferham, seemingly east of Edinburgh and west of Auldhame.”The western branch of the Peffer Burn flows into Aberlady, of course, and place-name evidence places the village on a route taken by monks travelling between the two great seats of learning of the Celtic Church at this time: Iona and Lindisfarne on Holy Island.This route became a holy highway connecting the two major religious sites, and one very likely taken by St Aidan, who left Iona to establish the church on Lindisfarne. In this context, a high cross here at Aberlady, or Pefferhamyou prefer, becomes quite plausible.More evidence emerged from metal finds in the Glebe Field immediately north of the present church. The tip of an ornately carved bishop’s crosier and a carved representation of Madonna and child had been found by metal detectorists lots of coins too. Moreover, geophysical research located two seemingly overlapping oblong structures, which could have been Anglo-Saxon but perhaps over large when compared with others. The evidence was cumulating and convinced Ian of the need for archaeological research. Historic Environment Scotland agreed and Historical Monument Consent was given, and a case for funding was submitted to the Heritage Lottery Fund.The project envisaged involving six local schools, as well as many local and not-so-local volunteers, and the funding was approved. The archaeological investigation in the Glebe Field, just north of the church, took place in .The results of the dig were astounding, revealing a signicant settlement of stone structures overlaying earlier timber structures dating to the seventh to th centuries. The largest collection of scattered metal objects dating from the Anglo-Saxon period ever discovered in Scotland came from the Glebe here, pointing firmly to a major settlement during that time.Ian happily told me that “prominent academic research experts have agreed that there is now sufficient artefactual, place-name and textual evidence to say that we can begin to tell the story of the ‘lost’ Anglo-Saxon settlement of Pefferham”. “In fact,” he added, “it seems that base hole for the original carved cross may have been discovered.”It was so fascinating to hear and there is not enough space here to go into all the details of the story, but fascinating leaflets have been produced by the conservation and history society which bring these exciting discoveries to le. But nothing compares to a visit to the village to view the locations and feel the presence of all this history, with brilliantly illustrated information and interpretative  by the society to guide your imagination.What has been achieved by Aberlady Conservation and History Society was summed up by Ruth Parsons, chief executive of Historic Environment Scotland, who has said: “The incredible work done by Aberlady Conservation and History Society has brought previously unknown history to light. It has added to our understanding of a period in history little understood, even by those who know most about it… this fabulous cross reconstruction is, quite simply, unique. Hopefully, it will stand for centuries.”I hope so too.

title: plans-new-housing-development-tranent-revealed
story: Members of the public can learn about Persimmon Homes East Scotland’s plans for land between Lammermoor Terrace and the industrial units off Elphinstone Road on Wednesday.The developer is yet to reveal how many new homes or what size the properties would be on the site, which is currently farmland.A spokesperson for Persimmon Homes East Scotland said: “Persimmon Homes will host an online interactive consultation event on Thursday, January , between pm and pm.“Members of the public are invited to post questions on the proposals and a member of our team will be online to answer.”A formal application would need to be submitted to East Lothian Council following the public consultation.Members of the public would be given another chance to look at the plans and make any comment before they are potentially scrutinised by the council’s planning committee.Mike Falconer, chairman of Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, encouraged any interested parties to attend the virtual consultation and find out more about the proposals. He added: “We have not had a meeting since the beginning of December and not had any chats about the plans.”The town’s four ward councillors, as well as the community council, were made aware of the early plans towards the end of November.When the proposals were submitted, a spokesperson for the developer said: “We are in the early stages of the planning process that could deliver much-needed new homes, investment and jobs in Tranent.“The land at Lammermoor Terrace has been allocated for housing in the adopted Local Development Plan and we are looking forward to welcoming stakeholders and the local community to the online consultation event to discuss our initial proposals.”A link to the proposals can be found at persimmonhomes lammermoor-terrace

title: honest-singers-welcome-visitors-market-newhailes-house
story: The vocalists entertained everyone in true festive style in the courtyard at the National Trust for Scotland attraction in the lead-up to Christmas.They performed a selection of Christmas carols, including Lie Low, which was written by choir leader Alison Vasey, and the New Year Carol, written by choir member Karen Austin.The Honest Singers were formed as a result of an evening class which Alison taught at Fisherrow Community Centre.“We are all enthusiastic members who just like singing and socialising,” said long-time choir member Yvonne Cunningham.The group decided to meet and perform occasionally.Past events have included busking to raise money for Marie Curie, Musselburgh-based CHANGES Community Health Project and Teapot Trust, which is also based in Musselburgh.

title: covid-east-lothian-hundreds-high-school-pupils-work-home
story: Five of the countys six high schools have made the decision to ask certain year groups to work from home due to crippling levels of staff absence related to Covid-.Youngsters in S to S at North Berwick High School - some in the midst of prelim exams - will begin studying remotely for at least a fortnight from tomorrow.S to S pupils from Dunbar Grammar School will begin remote learning for likely a similar period from Monday, while S- pupils from Haddingtons Knox Academy were working from home today and tomorrow .While Ss at Ross High School, Tranent, and Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, started working from home from today.At present, Musselburgh Grammar School has all year groups in school.Michelle Moore, headteacher of North Berwick High School, said to parents and carers in a letter today: "We were pleased to weclome all students back to school yesterday."However, the evolving situation regarding Covid does mean that we are facing some signicant challenges relating to staffing levels, meaning we need to take the decision to move some pupils to remote learning.: Classrooms go viral as county Covid cases rise "For this reason, we ask that from Friday our S- young people learn and study remotely throughout the upcoming prelim diet and only come into school when they have a prelim."Staff, she added, would continue to be available to support revision and learning however, teachers were likely to be covering younger year groups at times when they would usually be teaching senior phase.The headteacher asked parents and carers for "support and understanding that communication through Google Classroom or via email may be replied to flexibly"."We really appreciate your support of this arrangement during this very challenging time for schools in the light of high levels of staff absence," said Mrs Moore."We believe this solution will give more certainty to our pupils and families during this time."Meanwhile, today there were nine classes at primary schools in East Lothian who were working from home due to staff shortages.

title: secretary-haddingtons-community-council-resigns
story: Fiona McEwan had been a member of the group, which also covers Athelstaneford, for more than five years.However, Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, announced that his we had stepped down during a virtual meeting last month.He said: “I would like to say a big thank you to Fiona, who decided to resign and stepped down [earlier in the month].“I have to say, it was a bit of a shock to me as well as everybody .“I would like to thank her for many years’ service to the community council – it is fantastic the work she has done.“She is going to continue a little bit with the events group and organise stuff through that.”No successor was appointed on the night, with office bearers agreeing to cover the role until it was filled.

title: view-1921-census-via-findmypast-free
story: The  census holds details about how our ancestors lived and worked in the wake of the First World War and the Spanish flu pandemic.Taken on June , , the records hold information about nearly  million people who lived in England and Wales during a period of economic turmoil and when women had just won the right to vote.Heres what you need to know about viewing the  census online and in libraries.The  census is available online at findmypast as well as in person at the National Archives in Kew, the National Library of Wales in Aberystwyth, and the Manchester Central Library.Findmypast said the  Census will not immediately be free to view - but you can access it via any subscription, including libraries. Hi again, the free search will show birth place, birth location, full name and location of census, and a hover-over preview will indicate other names in the household, so we hope you can be confident with your purchase 🙂It will only be available via pay-per-view access for the initial period, Findmypast said.Viewing transcriptions costs £. per record while records can also be viewed as an image of the original document, viewing images costs £. per record.-month Pro subscribers via Findmypast can access a  per cent discount on all  Census purchases, according to Findmypast.Visitors to The National Archives in Kew will be able to view the  Census online for free via the Findmypast website, the National Archives said.This also applies to two regional hubs at Manchester Central Library and the National Library of Wales - access will be supported by the Manchester and Lancashire Family History Society helpdesk and the Archives+ Team.Some historians have raised concerns over pay-per-view access to the  census while others looking to analyse their family history complained online.One Twitter user said: "A bit misleading to advertise about the  census records, but not that theyre pay-per-view only. I get that its an expensive exercise to digitize, but be upfront and transparent."Another added: "My great grandfathers handwriting has just cost me a fortune in @findmypast costs. Well, that and the poor name iants option. Why isnt the #Census free to access  This is public information. I spot another great inequality."Catherine Warr, the historian behind YouTube channel Yorkshires Hidden History, said it was important to make "history accessible to all".The historian said: "As a working-class, non-academic historian, Im passionate about making history accessible to all."Whilst there are costs involved in digitising census records and it does involve a lot of work, all that keeping these records behind a paywall does is make it harder for historians and family researchers from lower economic backgrounds to access this information."The Welsh Newspaper Archive has managed to make millions of newspapers, from the th century to , free for everyone to access, demonstrating that keeping information behind a paywall is a choice, not an obligation. near Southampton. " alt"East Lothian Courier: Undated handout photo issued by Findmypast Tanya Nakamoto, a Findmypast conservator pushing a trolley of boxes containing some of the , bound volumes of the  Census, which take up . linear kilometres of shelving, at the Office for National Statisticsnear Southampton. " class"editor-image"Undated handout photo issued by Findmypast Tanya Nakamoto, a Findmypast conservator pushing a trolley of boxes containing some of the , bound volumes of the  Census, which take up . linear kilometres of shelving, at the Office for National Statisticsnear Southampton."If we want to make sure that genealogy and historical research is a welcoming and open hobby for all, we must make it easier for all people to access records - and that means making them free."Findmypast said it had made a "signicant investment" in "conserving, digitising, transcribing and building an experience that enables meaningful, accurate searches" of the  census.The  census saw teams from Findmypast and the National Archives carefully digitise more than , bound volumes of original documents, all stored on . linear kilometres of shelving. Speaking via the Findmypast website, Findmypast said: "Every page of the fragile physical documents had to be handled by a trained conservation technician who was responsible for a iety of delicate tasks, including removing any objects that could damage the paper, correcting folds covering the text, teasing apart pages that had become stuck together, restoring tears and checking for and repairing other damage."

title: opening-hours-corn-exchange-vaccination-centre-revealed
story: East Lothian Community Hospital, also in the town, closed its vaccination centre earlier this week.Residents are now being directed to either the Corn Exchange, on the town’s Court Street, or Musselburgh Primary Care Centre for appointments.A drop-in service is also available at the Haddington venue.From tomorrow , the building is open from .am to .pm seven days a week.East Lothian Council has also confirmed that - year olds can visit for their second doseat least  weeks since their first jab and they have not had Covid in the past  weeks.For appointment information, go to nhsinform.scot vaccinebooking

normalfont-weight: normalline-height: pxtext-decoration: none"target"_blank"A post shared by Young Scot Those aged between five and  years old, living in Scotland can apply for free bus travel from Monday, January .Children under-five can already travel on Scottish bus services for free and do not need a card to do so.You should only apply for the bus passyou are making essential journeys in line with current Scottish Government Covid- advice to stay at home as much as possible.Essential journeys could include travel for education, work, health or care needs, Transport Scotland has said.Young people will need either a new or replacement National Entitlement Cardor Young Scot National Entitlement Cardto access the free services. You will not be able to use a previously issued card to access the scheme and the photo must look like you to ride for free. Eligible Scots will be able to use their free bus travel card on all registered bus services in Scotland. This also includes a limited number of local cross border services from the South of Scotland into Northern England.If you are a parent or  applying on behalf of your child, please be aware that they will be able to ride the majority of services in most parts of Scotland before applying.However, there are a few services, including premium-fare night buses and City Sightseeing buses that are not included. Transport Scotland recommends that you check with the bus company before travelling.Traffic including buses driving through the city centre. Credit: PA While young people can apply for their free bus pass from Monday, January , the scheme will not officially start until January . Once you have applied, it should take ten working days after your application was approved before you receive the card. The processing time could be longer due to the current impact of the pandemic. You can apply for free bus travel in several dferent ways, including online and in-person.Aged - You will need to apply for an NEC card yourself.If youre applying online, you can use a smartphone, tablet or computer depending on what you prefer.To get your card, you will need either scanned documents or photographs for your proof of entitlement, make sure you have these read.Go to this website - GETYOURNEC.SCOT - to apply for your card.Under  Those aged between five and  years old must have a parent orapply on their behalf. As above, you will need scanned or photographed documents to prove eligibility. Users can go to the GETYOURNEC.SCOT website to register for the pass. If the young persons school uses it, you can also apply at parentsportal.scot on their behalf.If you dont have regular digital access, you can still benefit from the scheme by signing up in person. You can apply for a new or replacement NEC card at your local council office. See where your local council office is and how to get in touch with them via the Transport Scotland website.Some local councils may not be offering in-person applications due to the pandemic so you check the website or call before going to your council office. Some schools will be helping students with their applications in some council areas but schools will contact you directly about this arrangement.

title: busy-section-road-close-five-days
story: York Road, at its junction with A Dirleton Avenue to the junction with Cromwell Road, will be closed from today.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: "Local access for residents will be maintained where practicable whilst emergency services will have access maintained throughout."Residents should present their refuse collections as normal."Street parking on York Road will be prohibited during this time."

title: subscribe-east-lothian-courier-free-trial
story: In order to continue to deliver quality journalism everyday we ask our readers to support us with a subscription.This month we are giving you the opportunity to experience full access to all our unrivalled stories, as well as experiencing up to % less advertising, for free for  days.You can experience the free trial on either our monthly or annual plansyou subscribe today.If you take up our monthly plan, you will get the first  days free before the plan renews at the standard £..If you select our annual plan, after your -day free trial, the plan will cost you a single payment of £ for a year. This will save you % on our standard price.So why should you subscribe:Not only will you be supporting our local journalism, but you will also get advert-light access to our website. This means that reading the news will take up less bandwidth and pages will load even faster.You will also be able to pass the time with access to more than  new puzzles each week.Already this January, we have brought you numerous exclusives – some of which have been subscriber-only content.For example, we revealed that hundreds of secondary pupils have gone back to working from home – just two days after schools opened this term.We are also always on top of the latest planning news in the area, including plans to knock down and replace the current petrol station at Old Craighall.
